chapter.title: Chapter 10 Division
chapter.book_content_preview: Chapter 10 Division LEARNING OUTCOMES 10.1 Discuss the two stages of teaching division to young students and the sequence of problem types appropriate for each stage. 10.2 Describe the ways in which division can be introduced using concrete demonstrations. 10.3 Outline instructional strategies to teach single-digit division including problems without remainders, division facts, and problems with remainders. 10.4 Discuss the differences in the instructional strategies for teaching multi-digit division problems with one-digit divisors and two-digit divisors. SKILL HIERARCHY ♦ ••••••• As with all major operations, division is introduced in two stages: the beginning stage and the multi-digit division stage. During

judgment.reasoning: Although the 'Instructional Sequence and Assessment Chart' on page 182 lists 'Division equation with ÷ sign' as a problem type, the chapter provides no instructional procedures for this format. All teaching examples and formats focus exclusively on the long division notation (e.g., 5)20). Page 184 even recommends against the phrasing '20 divided by 5 equals 4', which is associated with the equation format, in favor of '5 goes into 20 four times'.

judgment.reasoning: The chapter explicitly covers the calculation of area and volume. The 'Instructional Sequence and Assessment Chart' lists 'Find the area of rectangle or square' (p. 462) and 'Find the volume of a box (rectangular prism)' (p. 464) as problem types, with examples using inches. The section 'CALCULATING PERIMETER, AREA, AND VOLUME' (p. 470) describes teaching the procedure for calculating area and volume, and notes that formats use 'a variety of common units such as inches, feet, yards'. A format for calculating the volume of boxes is also described (p. 473).
